questionParts: What is the expression for the unit normal vector \( \mathbf{n} \) on the surface of the upper hemisphere defined by \( x^2 + y^2 + z^2 = 1 \) and \( z \geq 0 \)?
explanationParts: The unit normal vector \( \mathbf{n} \) on the surface of a sphere centered at the origin with radius 1 is simply the position vector normalized to unit length. Since the position vector \( \mathbf{r} = x \mathbf{i} + y \mathbf{j} + z \mathbf{k} \) already has unit length on the surface of the sphere, the unit normal vector is \( \mathbf{n} = x \mathbf{i} + y \mathbf{j} + z \mathbf{k} \).

questionParts: Convert the Cartesian coordinates \( x, y, z \) into spherical coordinates for the vector field \( \mathbf{v} = \mathbf{i} + x \mathbf{j} + z \mathbf{k} \) and express the dot product \( \mathbf{v} \cdot \mathbf{n} \) in terms of spherical coordinates.
explanationParts: In spherical coordinates, the Cartesian coordinates are given by \( x = \cos \theta \sin \phi \), \( y = \sin \theta \sin \phi \), and \( z = \cos \phi \). Substituting these into the vector field \( \mathbf{v} \), we get \( \mathbf{v} = \mathbf{i} + \cos \theta \sin \phi \mathbf{j} + \cos \phi \mathbf{k} \).
The unit normal vector in spherical coordinates is \( \mathbf{n} = \cos \theta \sin \phi \mathbf{i} + \sin \theta \sin \phi \mathbf{j} + \cos \phi \mathbf{k} \).
